docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors aren't supposed to have favorite patients. But here's a poorly kept secret: we do. Mine was a 57-year-old man named Joe who died recently, after a 15-year battle against AIDS. Although I hadn't been Joe's physician for the several years, since I moved away from the city where he lived, we kept in close contact. Yesterday, I received a letter from his longtime partner, John, telling me that Joe had died from the disease that has shaped our era as starkly as bubonic plague framed the Renaissance. He was, as John put it, brave to his last breath.

headline.main: Those Magic Times When the Patient Makes the Doctor Feel Better

docs.abstract: Essay by Dr Howard Markel on his favorite patient, man who battled AIDS for ten years before dying; says patient changed way he understood adversity cause by illness and importance of having hope and faith, subjects rarely covered in medical school; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Franklin Chang-Diaz, a NASA astronaut with roots in Costa Rica, and Dr. Jose Zaglul, president of a university that specializes in agricultural courses for the humid tropics, were driving onto Dr. Zaglul's campus in Mercedes, Costa Rica, one day in 1991 when they had a short conversation that has turned into a big idea. Dr. Chang-Diaz, who was in Costa Rica to foster greater Latin American participation in space projects, had just met some Chilean scientists who were trying to cure Chagas' disease, a parasitic illness that kills about 45,000 people a year, mostly in Latin America. As leader of Earth University, or Escuela de Agricultura de la Region Tropical Humeda, Dr. Zaglul was passionate about teaching the importance of biodiversity and sustainable development of natural resources.

headline.main: From Jungle to Space in Pursuit of New Drugs

docs.abstract: Effort is under way to use space shuttle to develop drug to treat Chagas disease, parasitic illness that kills about 45,000 people a year, mostly in Latin America; drugs made through crystallization can be made more uniformly in microgravity of space; Dr Franklin Chang-Diaz, astronaut and physicist, and Dr Lawrence J DeLucas, biochemistry professor on leave to NASA, began string of Chagas experiments on space shuttle in 1996; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Dr. Franklin Chang-Diaz, a NASA astronaut with roots in Costa Rica, and Dr. Jose Zaglul, president of a university that specializes in agricultural courses for the humid tropics,  were driving onto Dr. Zaglul's campus in Mercedes, Costa Rica, one day...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the past, most health clubs with group exercise classes offered a variety ranging from about A to B. There was generally an aerobics class, another aerobics class and maybe a stretch class. But that has changed. There is now a vast array of group exercise classes that health clubs serve up.

headline.main: Sing-Along Aerobics at Your Corner Gym

docs.abstract: Health clubs are offering vast array of group exercise classes; photo (M)0

docs.lead_paragraph: For some pregnant women, depression does not always wait to be postpartum. Depression can come at any point in a woman's pregnancy, and if it does, she and her doctor can be in a quandary over whether to try antidepressants. Now researchers believe they may have found a way to help these women without exposing them and their fetuses to drugs. Turning to a technique sometimes used to help people with seasonal affective disorder, the gloom that can settle in as fall comes and the days grow shorter, the doctors have been trying light therapy on their patients.
docs.abstract: Researchers find light therapy has shown promising results in treating pregnant women who are depressed but cannot take antidepressants; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Obese people often lament the social penalties that can come with their condition, over and above the toll on their personal health. Now a new study has tried to put a price tag on the ostracism. For obese women in their 50's and 60's, the study found striking differences between their net worth and that of similarly placed women who were not obese.

headline.main: When Obesity Comes With a Price Tag

docs.abstract: New study finds that obese women in their 50's and 60's have net worth strikingly less than similarly placed women who are not obese; researchers say their findings are consistent with notion that obesity is economically burdensome for women (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Within 24 hours of quitting, the subjects reported symptoms: irritability, anxiety, and physical tension, to say nothing of other changes in mood and appetite. Had they given up cigarettes? Caffeine? Alcohol? Try marijuana, instead.

headline.main: Realities of Breaking a Marijuana Habit

docs.abstract: Researchers say their findings undercut notion that marijuana is benign; say withdrawal symptoms include irritability, anxiety and physical tension, as well as changes in mood and appetite; study is reported in Experimental and Clinical Psychopharmacology (S)
docs.snippet: Within 24 hours of quitting, the subjects reported symptoms: irritability, anxiety, and physical tension, to say nothing of other changes in mood and appetite.    Had they given up cigarettes? Caffeine? Alcohol? Try marijuana, instead.

docs.lead_paragraph: Losing a breast to cancer could come down to the luck of the draw for many women, according to a study released today. The specialist a woman chooses, and the surgeon's preference for either radical breast surgery (mastectomy) or surgery to remove the tumor only (lumpectomy), may determine a woman's course of treatment, the study said.

headline.main: Doctor Main Variable in Mastectomy Choice

docs.abstract: Study finds that woman's course of treatment for breast cancer may be determined by her surgeon's preference for either radical breast surgery (mastectomy) or surgery to remove tumor only (lumpectomy), even though several studies show that long-term survival rates differ little between two procedures for women with small breast tumors (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Athletes who take the sports supplement androstenedione, commonly known as andro, might want to pay attention to one new finding: the substance can make them fail urine tests for the banned anabolic steroid nandrolone. There is a simple enough explanation for this, the U.C.L.A. researchers who made the findings reported. Although the supplements' labels do not disclose it, in at least some cases, andro contains trace amounts of a metabolite that signals nandrolone use.

headline.main: Athletes, Andro and Trouble in the Urine

docs.abstract: Athletes who take sports supplement androstenedione, which is legal, may risk failing urine tests for banned anabolic steroid nandrolone; researchers find that andro contains trace amounts of metabolite that signals nandrolone use; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To a patient, few things look bigger than that needle a doctor is about to plunge who-knows-where to administer a vaccine. But some doctors are arguing that in many cases, those syringes ought to be even bigger.
docs.abstract: Doctors writing in The British Medical Journal say some vaccine needles are too small to be effective; cite recent study finding that standard needle could not penetrate upper arms of 17 percent of men and 50 percent of women because of variations in thickness of fat; photo (S)
docs.snippet: To a patient, few things look bigger than that needle a doctor is about to plunge who-knows-where to administer a vaccine.    But some doctors are arguing that in many cases, those syringes ought to be even bigger.

docs.lead_paragraph: Faithful readers know that I've been plagued by arthritic pain in both knees for about a decade and that I've experienced significant symptomatic improvement after daily use of a dietary supplement that combines glucosamine and chondroitin. About six months ago, I also began wearing magnetic knee sleeves when I played tennis and sometimes for my daily three-mile walk. In addition to being a lot more comfortable than those Neoprene knee braces I used to wear, the magnetic sleeves seem to have done more to minimize my discomfort during knee-stressing activities.

headline.main: Less Pain: Is It in the Magnets or the Mind?

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on therapeutic magnets for pain relief; notes that Americans spend more than $300 million a year on magnets, and many of them swear that their pain is relieved; says well-designed, placebo-controlled studies of magnet therapy have been rare, and even researchers who are among leading proponents of magnet theraply concede that larger and better-controlled studies are needed before this approach can rightfully join cadre of alternative therapies that are clearly effective; photo (M)
